Hurst, a British civil servant, is credited with bringing the power law distribution into popular usage. Faced with the task of protecting Egypt against floods on the Nile rive, he did an exhaustive analysis of the frequency of high and low water marks at dozens of other rivers around the world. He found that the range widened far more than would be predicted by the normal distribution. In fact, he devised a measure, called the Hurst exponent, to capture the widening of the range; the Hurst exponent which has a value of 0.5 for the normal distribution had a value of 0.73 for the rivers that he studied. In intuitive terms, his findings suggested that there were extended periods of rainfall that were better-than-expected and worse- than-expected that caused the widening of the ranges.
